message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and MRI findings suggest hydrocephalus, which is a buildup of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery is the most appropriate treatment to drain the excess fluid and relieve the pressure on the brain. Cerebral aqueductoplasty is another surgery option, but ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the more common and effective procedure. Furosemide and acetazolamide are not appropriate treatments for hydrocephalus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and MRI findings suggest hydrocephalus, and the most appropriate treatment would be a Ventriculoperitoneal shunt to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid from the brain. Cerebral aqueductoplasty is not appropriate for this type of hydrocephalus. Furosemide and Acetazolamide therapy are not effective in treating hydrocephalus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hydrocephalus, which is confirmed by the MRI. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the most appropriate treatment for hydrocephalus. Cerebral aqueductoplasty is a procedure to treat aqueductal stenosis, which causes hydrocephalus. Furosemide and acetazolamide may be used to decrease cerebrospinal fluid production, but they are not effective in treating hydrocephalus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs and symptoms of hydrocephalus, including a bulging anterior fontanelle and enlarged ventricles on MRI. The most appropriate treatment in this case would be a ventriculoperitoneal shunt to divert the cerebrospinal fluid from the brain to the peritoneum. Cerebral aqueductoplasty is not appropriate in this case as the enlargement of all four ventricles suggest a generalized obstruction rather than a specific area. Furosemide and acetazolamide are diuretics that may be used in some cases of hydrocephalus but are not the first-line treatment for this patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hydrocephalus, which is confirmed by the MRI. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the most appropriate treatment to relieve the excess buildup of cerebrospinal fluid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and MRI findings suggest hydrocephalus, and ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the most appropriate treatment. Options A, C, and D are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The child’s symptoms suggest hydrocephalus, which is confirmed by the MRI. The most appropriate treatment for hydrocephalus is a ventriculoperitoneal shunt, which will drain the excess cerebrospinal fluid and help reduce the pressure in the brain. Options A, C, and D are not appropriate for treating hydrocephalus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and MRI findings suggest hydrocephalus, and the most appropriate treatment for hydrocephalus is ventriculoperitoneal shunt, which diverts the cerebrospinal fluid from the ventricles to the peritoneal cavity. Cerebral aqueductoplasty is used to treat aqueductal stenosis, a rare cause of hydrocephalus. Furosemide and acetazolamide are not effective treatments for hydrocephalus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of the patient and the MRI findings suggest hydrocephalus. The most appropriate treatment is ventriculoperitoneal shunt. Cerebral aqueductoplasty is a less common option and is performed only in certain cases. Furosemide and acetazolamide therapies are not effective treatments for hydrocephalus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and MRI findings suggest hydrocephalus. The most appropriate treatment is ventriculoperitoneal shunt, which helps to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid and relieve pressure on the brain. Cerebral aqueductoplasty, furosemide therapy, and acetazolamide therapy are not appropriate treatments for hydrocephalus.
